content.title: Email Thread
content.visibleText: Dragos Nita: So there is a definite 'we're used to doing things this way' mindset, and I think there could be more engagement where we make the knowledge more available. (June 10) Dragos Nita: I think we don't need to worry about their internal processes, we just need to build features that work good and are simple and people will use them (assuming they are enabled for it) (June 10) Dragos Nita: The fact that they feel the need to prepare internal training material for new features tells us the UK lacks it. (June 10) Viraj: Yeah, I agree (June 10) Yahya: Yeah, sure (June 10) Viraj: I suggest (June 10)

content.title: Email Thread
content.visibleText: Dragos Nita: Who are these comms managers? Seriously, are they police officers at some companies? MT, who lives in Atlanta, Christine Arnold and Quest Diagnostics said this directly after the meeting. It still bugs them even for just 2nd most recent customer for example, and CCO didn't know them. Not only are they so nosy they decide to document all latest gossip, who can consider it speed up the process of crippling Cecily for everyone. (June 10)

I just want to build features that work good and that are simple and people will use them (assuming they are enabled for everyone).

The fact that they feel the need to prepare internal training material for new features tells us the UK sucks ðŸ˜ž

Yes, I know, but I am just referring to the problem we have created...

content.title: Email Thread
content.visibleText:
From: Customer Feedback <feedback@customer.com>

Subject: Re: Your company's new features

Hello,

Also, from some customers, I've heard them saying 'we've told the multiple times in the years of our partnership, which shows they have been engaging before (unlike some that come from nowhere and demand a lot of our attention). It's easier for old clients to be met and addressed, like they're hurt in this process, and we need templates, as they have a lot of our engagement in ongoing communication to get to their old concerns before hearing about new features.

1. Importing for analysis (HubSpot mentioned a recent Power BI skills training session and ongoing use for adapting to new tools).

2. Having better customer relations (including video sessions).

3. How HubSpot is adapting a very critical core of its (this is partly related to our core values as a company and a lot of effort by our team).

Best regards,

Customer Feedback Team

uiElements.details: Ribbon with Home, Insert, Design, Transitions, Animations, Slide Show, Review, View tabs, and slide editing area.

content.title: Slide Content
content.visibleText:
Hello ðŸ‘‹ First name,

We are now starting to send educational videos to better address the pain points you experience and also the wishes shared with us so you can learn about CoPilot. We hope everyone can else can benefit from this knowledge.

Today's video is about how we ensure your data when you use CoPilot. Understandably, there were questions regarding data security, and we want to address these concerns even more explicitly and informatively.

Watch the video below to learn more about our commitment to keeping your data secure and ensuring no AI is ever being trained on your data.

How does CoPilot use your data?

Q: Do you or any 3rd parties train on our Data?
A: In short, no.

Any data used by CoPilot or CoPilot AI is not being used to train any HubSpot account for OpenAI, which disables training on user data.

activitySummary: The user is actively engaged in email communication and chat within Gmail. They are part of a conversation in the 'Central PMS team' chat, discussing internal processes and feature development. The conversation includes multiple participants, and the user is contributing to the discussion by responding to messages and providing input on the topics being discussed. The chat interface shows a detailed thread of messages exchanged over several days.

The user is also working on a document in Google Docs. The document appears to be related to an educational series titled 'Jive CoPilot - Educational Series Part 1'. The user is editing text, adjusting formatting, and ensuring the content is well-structured. The document includes sections on data security and the use of CoPilot, addressing common questions and concerns from users. The user is focused on creating clear and informative content for the educational series.

Throughout the captured period, the user is primarily using Google Chrome to access Gmail and Google Docs. The Gmail interface shows multiple tabs open, including email threads and chat conversations. The user is managing their email and chat communications efficiently, switching between different threads and responding to messages promptly. The Google Docs interface shows the user actively editing and formatting the document, indicating a focus on content creation and refinement.

The user is primarily engaged in email communication and document editing without any interaction with AI assistants or embedded AI chat interfaces. The focus is on manual input and content creation rather than leveraging AI for assistance or automation.
